introduction.p: In this activity, we explore two different functions and classify the points at which each is not differentiable.
For (a)-(c), let g be the function given by the rule g(x) = |x|.

statement.p: Reasoning graphically (that is, by discussing the graph of g(x)=|x|), explain why g is differentiable at every point x such that x \ne 0.

hint.p: What type of function is g for all x \lt 0? For all x > 0?

solution.p: We know that g(x) = |x| is given by the formula g(x) = -x when x \lt 0 and by g(x) = x when x \ge 0. Each of these pieces of g is a straight line, so at every point other than the point where they meet, the function g has a well-defined slope, and thus is differentiable.

statement.p: Use the limit definition of the derivative to show that g'(0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{|h|}{h}.
Explain why g'(0) fails to exist by using small positive and negative values of h.

hint.p: What is the value of |h| when h \lt 0?

solution.p:
Following up on our work in (b), note that whenever h > 0, |h| = h, and thus
\lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{|h|}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{h}{h} = 1 , while whenever h \lt 0, |h| = -h, and thus
\lim_{h \to 0^-} \frac{|h|}{h} = \lim_{h \to 0^-} \frac{-h}{h} = -1
Since the right- and left-hand limits are not equal, it follows that
g'(0) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{|h|}{h}
does not exist.

statement.p: Let f be the function that we have previously explored in Preview Activity, whose graph is given again in the following figure.
State all values of a for which f is not differentiable at x = a. For each, provide a reason for your conclusion.

hint.p: You might start by identifying points where f is not continuous.

solution.p: f is not differentiable at a = -2, -1, 2, 3 because at each of these points f is not continuous. In addition, f is not differentiable at a = -3 and a = 1 because the graph of f has a corner point (or cusp) at each of these values.

statement.p: True or false: if a function p is differentiable at x = b, then \lim_{x \to b} p(x) must exist. Why?

hint.p: What does being differentiable at a point tell you about continuity there?

solution.p: True: if a function p is differentiable at x = b, then \lim_{x \to b} p(x) must exist. This is true because we know that if p is differentiable at a point, then p is continuous there, and anytime a function is continuous at a point, it must have a limit there.
